intro: Crepis suffreniana var. apula, commonly known as the Apulian mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its small, hairy leaves and yellowish composite flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and coastal areas. It is a perennial herb that can reach heights of up to 30 cm, and it produces achenes as its seeds. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
